prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACS0416-2403 Band6 mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the HST frontier field MACS0416 at band 6 in 1mm continuum. This mosaic will cover the central portion of the HST WFC3 footprint in 100"x150".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will carry out a mosaic mapping of a region around the cluster center mass with 100"x130". The proposed observation is basically a continuum mapping observation in Band 6. We will take advantage of ALMA wide bandwidth of 8GHz for 4 spectral windows (2GHz each). Since our primary science goal is to target high-redshift, sub-luminous star forming galaxies, we want to use the full 34 atennas and achieve the spatial resolution of 0.2", matching with that of HST WFC3 data. This will allow the unambiguous counterpart identifications.
To make the most efficient map, we will use spacing of 0.5 of the main beam. With this spacing option, we need a total of 68 pointings to cover the full area of 100"x130". We plan to reach 1sigma rms of 35uJy in the final mosaiced map. The justification for this sensitivity is fully described in the proposal. The salient point is that our promary science drivers are to reach sub-luminous (the Milky Way like) star forming galaxies (L(ir) ~ 5x10^10Lsun) at redshifts ~ 4 - 6. This requires our band 6 cotninuum map reaching rms of 35uJy. Of course, this faint level of luminosity is also made possible by the strong lensing magnification provided by the clusters' massive dark matter halos.
We will have four spectral windows, each with bandwidth of 2GHz and resolution of (41-44)km/s. The representative spectral window is selected at 212GHz. The four spectral windows, covering (212-230)GHz, will allow us to measure the spectral slopes for all detected sources. Although the frequency range is not very large, the flux ratios will provide important indication on the far-IR cold dust temperatures.
We will use the system-defined calibration. Although we feel that these calibrations were not optimally defined for the most efficient mosaic mapping, we did not want to make too many changes to the standard calibration procedures and overly burden the ALMA science operation teams. For example, it is possible to reduce the number of times the absolute flux calibrators are being observed for the mosaic map. This will reduce overhead and calibration time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Abell2744 Band6 mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the HST frontier field Abell2744 at band 6 in 1mm continuum. This mosaic will cover the central footprint of the HST WFC3 coverage with 100"x130".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will carry out a mosaic mapping of a region around the cluster center mass with 100"x100". The proposed observation is basically a continuum mapping observation in Band 6. We will take advantage of ALMA wide bandwidth of 8GHz for 4 spectral windows (2GHz each). Since our primary science goal is to target high-redshift, sub-luminous star forming galaxies, we want to use the full 34 atennas and achieve the spatial resolution of 0.2", matching with that of HST WFC3 data. This will allow the unambiguous counterpart identifications.
To make the most efficient map, we will use spacing of 0.5 of the main beam. With this spacing option, we need a total of 52 pointings to cover the full area of 100"x100". We plan to reach 1sigma rms of 35uJy in the final mosaiced map. The justification for this sensitivity is fully described in the proposal. The salient point is that our promary science drivers are to reach sub-luminous (the Milky Way like) star forming galaxies (L(ir) ~ 5x10^10Lsun) at redshifts ~ 4 - 6. This requires our band 6 cotninuum map reaching rms of 35uJy. Of course, this faint level of luminosity is also made possible by the strong lensing magnification provided by the clusters' massive dark matter halos.
We will have four spectral windows, each with bandwidth of 2GHz and resolution of (41-44)km/s. The representative spectral window is selected at 212GHz. The four spectral windows, covering (212-230)GHz, will allow us to measure the spectral slopes for all detected sources. Although the frequency range is not very large, the flux ratios will provide important indication on the far-IR cold dust temperatures.
We will use the system-defined calibration. Although we feel that these calibrations were not optimally defined for the most efficient mosaic mapping, we did not want to make too many changes to the standard calibration procedures and overly burden the ALMA science operation teams. For example, it is possible to reduce the number of times the absolute flux calibrators are being observed for the mosaic map. This will reduce overhead and calibration time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MACS1149+2223 Band6 mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the HST frontier field MACS1149 at band 6 in 1mm continuum. This mosaic will cover the same footprint of the HST WFC3 coverage of 3'x3'.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will carry out a mosaic mapping of a region around the cluster center mass with 100"x110". The proposed observation is basically a continuum mapping observation in Band 6. We will take advantage of ALMA wide bandwidth of 8GHz for 4 spectral windows (2GHz each). Since our primary science goal is to target high-redshift, sub-luminous star forming galaxies, we want to use the full 34 atennas and achieve the spatial resolution of 0.2", matching with that of HST WFC3 data. This will allow the unambiguous counterpart identifications.
To make the most efficient map, we will use spacing of 0.5 of the main beam. With this spacing option, we need a total of 60 pointings to cover the full area of 100"x110". We plan to reach 1sigma rms of 35uJy in the final mosaiced map. The justification for this sensitivity is fully described in the proposal. The salient point is that our promary science drivers are to reach sub-luminous (the Milky Way like) star forming galaxies (L(ir) ~ 5x10^10Lsun) at redshifts ~ 4 - 6. This requires our band 6 cotninuum map reaching rms of 35uJy. Of course, this faint level of luminosity is also made possible by the strong lensing magnification provided by the clusters' massive dark matter halos.
We will have four spectral windows, each with bandwidth of 2GHz and resolution of (41-44)km/s. The representative spectral window is selected at 212GHz. The four spectral windows, covering (212-230)GHz, will allow us to measure the spectral slopes for all detected sources. Although the frequency range is not very large, the flux ratios will provide important indication on the far-IR cold dust temperatures.
We will use the system-defined calibration. Although we feel that these calibrations were not optimally defined for the most efficient mosaic mapping, we did not want to make too many changes to the standard calibration procedures and overly burden the ALMA science operation teams. For example, it is possible to reduce the number of times the absolute flux calibrators are being observed for the mosaic map. This will reduce overhead and calibration time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Hubble and Spitzer Space Telescopes are dedicating 560 orbits and 800 hrs respectively to obtain the deepest, multi-band imaging of four galaxy clusters. These clusters are specially chosen to have the strongest gravitational lensing over large areas, enabling studies of z~2-8 galaxies intrinsically much fainter than any previous surveys. We request 27.8 hrs to obtain deep 1.2mm maps of three of these clusters, covering a total of 9.44 sq. arcmin, reaching 1sigma rms of 35uJy. Our survey have 4.3 and 2 sq. arcmin areas with lensing magnification of 3 & 10 respectively at z~4-8, thus (3-10) times deeper than ALMA UDF data. Cluster lensing plus additional advantage of strong negative K-correction for 1.2mm observations at high-z make it possible for the first time to detect far-IR emission from 252 galaxies at z>2, with 67 at z~4-8 down to intrinsically low L(IR)~(2-5)x10^{10}Lsun, similar to that of the Milky Way. The combined HST/Spitzer/ALMA data will provide the necessary far-IR data for a whole suite of new studies of galaxies at z~4-8. This includes a direct test of the recent claim that z~6-8 UV identified galaxies have less dust than those at z~4.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
